III. Relative Motion Equations in the Restricted Three-Body Problem
A. Exact Relative Dynamics
Consider a target and a chaser spacecraft orbiting around the Moon and subject to both Earth and Moon gravitational influences. Their equations of motions with respect to the Moon are given by Eq. (3):
:formula: (9)

IV. Simplification of the Equations of Relative Motion
Because of the nonlinearity of the gravitational acceleration and the presence of several time-varying parameters, the equations of relative motions derived in Sec. III, namely, Eq. (14), along with angular velocity and acceleration vectors given by Eqs. (31) and (32), may be difficult to use for the development of guidance and navi- gation systems. Two possible simplifications are here discussed, aimed at linearizing the equation set and at reducing the number of time-varying parameters.
A. CR3BP Assumption
Under the assumption of primaries revolving in circular orbits, the number of time-varying parameters in Eq. (14) reduces. As a matter of fact, in the CR3BP setup we have the following simplifications:
:formula:
The angular velocity and acceleration of the LVLH frame with respect to the inertial frame simplify as follows:
:formula:

In addition, the computation of the target acceleration and jerk in Eqs. (31b) and (32b) becomes:
:formula: :formula: :formula: :formula: (33) (34)
B. Linearization of the Gravitational Acceleration
Consider the gravitational acceleration on the chaser, due to the two primaries:
:formula:
These terms can be linearized by means of a Taylor expansion to the first order around the target position. For the lunar gravitational acceleration term we have:
:formula:
whereas for the Earth gravitational acceleration term:
:formula: :formula: :formula:
Hence, the right-hand side of Eq. (14) can be approximated as follows:
:formula: :formula:
obtaining a linear expression of the gravitation accelerations, with respect to the relative position vector.
C. Relative Motion Equation Sets
The possible simplifications discussed in the previous section can be used to derive four equation sets, which describe the relative dynamics with different levels of accuracy.
In the following, the skew symmetric matrices associated with angular velocity and acceleration vectors :formula: and :formula: that is:
:formula:
where
:formula:
are introduced to express the equations of motion in a more compact form.
1. ER3BP-Based Equations: ENERM and ELERM
If the ER3BP problem is considered, then the Moon motion is governed by the classical two-body problem equations, with the Earth as primary body. The quantities :formula: :formula: and :formula: can then be obtained accordingly.
With the name of elliptic nonlinear equations of relative motion (ENERM) we will refer to the following equation set:
:formula: :formula:
(35)
characterized by the following time-varying parameters that depend on target and on Moon orbital motion:
:formula:
:formula:

vector :formula: then Eq. (35) can be written as a nonlinear system affine in the control:
:formula:
where :formula: is the :formula: identity matrix, and :formula: is the :formula: zero matrix.
The gravitational acceleration can be linearized as discussed in Sec. IV.B, obtaining the elliptic linear equations of relative motion (ELERM):
:formula: :formula:
with angular velocities and accelerations computed as for the ENERM. Assuming the chaser controllable in acceleration, Eq. (36) can be written in state-space form as follows:

B. Linearization of the Gravitational Acceleration
Consider the gravitational acceleration on the chaser, due to the
two primaries:
These terms can be linearized by means of a Taylor expansion to
the first order around the target position. For the lunar gravitational
acceleration term we have:
whereas for the Earth gravitational acceleration term:
Hence, the right-hand side of Eq. (14) can be approximated as
follows:
obtaining a linear expression of the gravitation accelerations, with
respect to the relative position vector.
C. Relative Motion Equation Sets
The possible simplifications discussed in the previous section can
be used to derive four equation sets, which describe the relative
dynamics with different levels of accuracy.
In the following, the skew symmetric matrices associated with
angular velocity and acceleration vectors :formula: and :formula: that is:
where
are introduced to express the equations of motion in a more compact
form.
1. ER3BP-Based Equations: ENERM and ELERM
If the ER3BP problem is considered, then the Moon motion is
governed by the classical two-body problem equations, with the Earth
as primary body. The quantities :formula: :formula: and :formula: can then be
obtained accordingly.
With the name of elliptic nonlinear equations of relative motion
(ENERM) we will refer to the following equation set:
characterized by the following time-varying parameters that depend
on target and on Moon orbital motion:

For the sake of simplicity, in the following sections the overlying tilde will be dropped, and derivation with respect to the normalized time will be denoted with the Newton notation. Thus, all variables and parameters must be considered normalized.
III. Relative Motion Equations in the Restricted Three-Body Problem

where :formula: and :formula: denote target and chaser position with respect to the Moon.

IV. Simplification of the Equations of Relative Motion

Because of the nonlinearity of the gravitational acceleration and the presence of several time-varying parameters, the equations of relative motions derived in Sec. III, namely, Eq. (14), along with angular velocity and acceleration vectors given by Eqs. (31) and (32), may be difficult to use for the development of guidance and navi- gation systems. Two possible simplifications are here discussed, aimed at linearizing the equation set and at reducing the number of time-varying parameters.

Under the assumption of primaries revolving in circular orbits, the number of time-varying parameters in Eq. (14) reduces. As a matter of fact, in the CR3BP setup we have the following simplifications:
The angular velocity and acceleration of the LVLH frame with respect to the inertial frame simplify as follows:
